newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Product Swaps - Diesel up on new prompt demand.
newsitem.headline: Asia Product Swaps - Diesel up on new prompt demand.

text.p: Singapore gas oil swaps extended its early day rally late afternoon on Tuesday despite a weaker crude on expectations of continued physical purchases by a local trader.
"Gas oil firmed because of what happened last night and people expect Hin Leong to continue buying," one trader said.
April gas oil was last quoted at $26.30/$26.50 per barrel up from Monday's $25.85/$26.00, brokers said.
The market traded earlier in the day at $26.30 and $26.40 per barrel, they said.

May gas oil was last quoted at $25.25/$25.35, up about 30 cents from Monday. May gas oil traded at $25.00 and $25.05 while April/May was traded at $1.00 per barrel compared to the 85 cents traded late last week.
Traders said most players expected local trader Hin Leong to continue buying physical cargoes at least for another week and the higher swaps prices were a reflection of this.

On Monday, Hin Leong bought four cargoes of 150,000-barrels each at between $26.50 and 26.80 per barrel for end April lifting, free-on-board Singapore, taking their purchase tally to nearly 7.0 million barrels since March 3.
The hikes came despite a 30 cent fall to May Brent crude prices on London's International Petroleum Exchange to last trade at $19.08 per barrel.
Overnight May WTI crude on NYMEX fell 29 cents to $20.40 per barrel.
The jet fuel/gas oil spread or regrade was quoted unchanged at -50/-30 cents. April regrade traded earlier Tuesday at -43 cents, brokers said.
Fuel oil swaps were also quoted unchanged in quiet trade with April seen at $99.50/$100.50. Brokers said it traded earlier in the day at $99.50 and $99.75 per tonne.
